title: How to Clean an Oven with Baking Soda

steps.headline: Take out the oven racks.
steps.description: You should also remove anything else that is inside the oven, such as pizza stones or oven thermometers. Check to make sure nothing is left inside of the oven before you begin cleaning.

steps.headline: Scrape out the loose build-up.
steps.description: You may have a lot of burnt food and build-up in your oven. Try to remove as much of the loose build-up as possible before applying the baking soda. Use a plastic or silicone spatula to scrape off the loose matter. You don’t have to remove it all—just remove what is already loose or nearly loose.

steps.headline: Create a paste with baking soda and water.
steps.description: Mix ½ cup (170 g) of baking soda with 3 tablespoons (14.8 mL) of water in a small bowl. Stir the mixture until it forms a paste that can be easily spread. Adjust the amount of water used if 3 tablespoons does not create a spreadable paste.

steps.headline: Spread the paste inside of the oven.
steps.description: You can spread the paste by hand if you’re wearing rubber gloves. If that doesn’t work for you, you can also spread the paste with a clean spatula. Coat the interior of the oven with the paste. Do not apply the paste to the heating elements. It’s okay if the paste turns brown or is chunky in some areas of the oven. EXPERT TIP																															Chris Willatt																Cleaning Guru								Chris Willatt is the owner and founder of Alpine Maids, a cleaning agency in Denver, Colorado started in 2015. Alpine Maids has received Angie's List Super Service Award for three years in a row since 2016 and has been awarded Colorado's "Top Rated Local House Cleaning" Award in 2018. Chris Willatt			Cleaning Guru				Baking soda is an effective all-natural cleaner. Chris Willatt of Alpine Maids says: "Make a paste out of baking soda and water and cover the whole inside of the oven. Let it sit for about an hour, which gives the baking soda time to bind with the grease. When it's done, wipe it out, then scrub any baked-on grease that's left with a pumice stone or a scouring pad."

steps.headline: Leave the paste on overnight.
steps.description: The paste works best if you allow it to sit overnight or for 12 hours. If you don’t have that much time, you can let the paste sit for 40 minutes. You may have to repeat the process for a deep clean if you let it sit for a short amount of time, however.

steps.headline: Wipe off the baking soda.
steps.description: Use a damp cloth to wipe off the paste after you’ve let it sit. Use warm water to dampen the cloth. You may have to firmly scrub to get most of the paste off.

steps.headline: Scrape off the rest of the paste.
steps.description: You may have trouble getting all of the paste off with a damp cloth. If that’s the case, use a spatula to get the rest of the paste off of the oven. There may be some leftover residue, but that’s okay because you will use vinegar to remove it.

steps.headline: Spray vinegar inside of the oven.
steps.description: Pour white vinegar into a spray bottle. Spray the vinegar over the areas where residue remains from the paste. The vinegar will cause the baking soda to foam up.

steps.headline: Wipe down the oven again.
steps.description: Use a damp cloth to wipe off the foamy areas of the oven. If residue remains, use more vinegar and then wipe again. Continue to wipe until your oven is clean.

steps.headline: Clean the oven racks.
steps.description: Sprinkle baking soda over the oven racks. Then, pour or spray white vinegar onto the racks. The baking soda should begin to foam. When that happens, submerge the racks into a tub or hot water. Allow the racks to sit in the water overnight.

steps.headline: Replace the oven racks.
steps.description: Once you are finished cleaning, put the oven racks back into the oven. You can also put back in whatever you’ve taken out of the oven. Your oven is now ready for use.

text: Coating the Oven Take out the oven racks. You should also remove anything else that is inside the oven, such as pizza stones or oven thermometers. Check to make sure nothing is left inside of the oven before you begin cleaning. Scrape out the loose build-up. You may have a lot of burnt food and build-up in your oven. Try to remove as much of the loose build-up as possible before applying the baking soda. Use a plastic or silicone spatula to scrape off the loose matter. You don’t have to remove it all—just remove what is already loose or nearly loose. Create a paste with baking soda and water. Mix ½ cup (170 g) of baking soda with 3 tablespoons (14.8 mL) of water in a small bowl. Stir the mixture until it forms a paste that can be easily spread. Adjust the amount of water used if 3 tablespoons does not create a spreadable paste. Spread the paste inside of the oven. You can spread the paste by hand if you’re wearing rubber gloves. If that doesn’t work for you, you can also spread the paste with a clean spatula. Coat the interior of the oven with the paste. Do not apply the paste to the heating elements. It’s okay if the paste turns brown or is chunky in some areas of the oven. EXPERT TIP																															Chris Willatt																Cleaning Guru								Chris Willatt is the owner and founder of Alpine Maids, a cleaning agency in Denver, Colorado started in 2015. Alpine Maids has received Angie's List Super Service Award for three years in a row since 2016 and has been awarded Colorado's "Top Rated Local House Cleaning" Award in 2018. Chris Willatt			Cleaning Guru				Baking soda is an effective all-natural cleaner. Chris Willatt of Alpine Maids says: "Make a paste out of baking soda and water and cover the whole inside of the oven. Let it sit for about an hour, which gives the baking soda time to bind with the grease. When it's done, wipe it out, then scrub any baked-on grease that's left with a pumice stone or a scouring pad." Wiping Down the Oven Leave the paste on overnight. The paste works best if you allow it to sit overnight or for 12 hours. If you don’t have that much time, you can let the paste sit for 40 minutes. You may have to repeat the process for a deep clean if you let it sit for a short amount of time, however. Wipe off the baking soda. Use a damp cloth to wipe off the paste after you’ve let it sit. Use warm water to dampen the cloth. You may have to firmly scrub to get most of the paste off. Scrape off the rest of the paste. You may have trouble getting all of the paste off with a damp cloth. If that’s the case, use a spatula to get the rest of the paste off of the oven. There may be some leftover residue, but that’s okay because you will use vinegar to remove it. Finishing with Vinegar Spray vinegar inside of the oven. Pour white vinegar into a spray bottle. Spray the vinegar over the areas where residue remains from the paste. The vinegar will cause the baking soda to foam up. Wipe down the oven again. Use a damp cloth to wipe off the foamy areas of the oven. If residue remains, use more vinegar and then wipe again. Continue to wipe until your oven is clean. Clean the oven racks. Sprinkle baking soda over the oven racks. Then, pour or spray white vinegar onto the racks. The baking soda should begin to foam. When that happens, submerge the racks into a tub or hot water. Allow the racks to sit in the water overnight. Replace the oven racks. Once you are finished cleaning, put the oven racks back into the oven. You can also put back in whatever you’ve taken out of the oven. Your oven is now ready for use.

You should also remove anything else that is inside the oven, such as pizza stones or oven thermometers.
Check to make sure nothing is left inside of the oven before you begin cleaning.
Scrape out the loose build-up.
You may have a lot of burnt food and build-up in your oven.
Try to remove as much of the loose build-up as possible before applying the baking soda.
Use a plastic or silicone spatula to scrape off the loose matter.
You don’t have to remove it all—just remove what is already loose or nearly loose.
Create a paste with baking soda and water.
Mix ½ cup (170 g) of baking soda with 3 tablespoons (14.8 mL) of water in a small bowl.
Stir the mixture until it forms a paste that can be easily spread.
Adjust the amount of water used if 3 tablespoons does not create a spreadable paste.
Spread the paste inside of the oven.
You can spread the paste by hand if you’re wearing rubber gloves.
If that doesn’t work for you, you can also spread the paste with a clean spatula.
Coat the interior of the oven with the paste.
Do not apply the paste to the heating elements.
It’s okay if the paste turns brown or is chunky in some areas of the oven.

Chris Willatt			Cleaning Guru				Baking soda is an effective all-natural cleaner.
Chris Willatt of Alpine Maids says: "Make a paste out of baking soda and water and cover the whole inside of the oven.
Let it sit for about an hour, which gives the baking soda time to bind with the grease.
When it's done, wipe it out, then scrub any baked-on grease that's left with a pumice stone or a scouring pad."
Wiping Down the Oven Leave the paste on overnight.
The paste works best if you allow it to sit overnight or for 12 hours.
If you don’t have that much time, you can let the paste sit for 40 minutes.
You may have to repeat the process for a deep clean if you let it sit for a short amount of time, however.
Wipe off the baking soda.
Use a damp cloth to wipe off the paste after you’ve let it sit.
Use warm water to dampen the cloth.
You may have to firmly scrub to get most of the paste off.
Scrape off the rest of the paste.
You may have trouble getting all of the paste off with a damp cloth.
If that’s the case, use a spatula to get the rest of the paste off of the oven.
There may be some leftover residue, but that’s okay because you will use vinegar to remove it.
Finishing with Vinegar Spray vinegar inside of the oven.
Pour white vinegar into a spray bottle.
Spray the vinegar over the areas where residue remains from the paste.
The vinegar will cause the baking soda to foam up.
Wipe down the oven again.
Use a damp cloth to wipe off the foamy areas of the oven.
If residue remains, use more vinegar and then wipe again.
Continue to wipe until your oven is clean.
Clean the oven racks.
Sprinkle baking soda over the oven racks.
Then, pour or spray white vinegar onto the racks.
The baking soda should begin to foam.
When that happens, submerge the racks into a tub or hot water.
Allow the racks to sit in the water overnight.
Replace the oven racks.
Once you are finished cleaning, put the oven racks back into the oven.
You can also put back in whatever you’ve taken out of the oven.
Your oven is now ready for use.
